key_insight: LASER shows that you can convert high-quality offline feed-forward 4D reconstruction models into streaming-capable systems without retraining by aligning layer-wise activation scales, enabling causal inference with greatly reduced memory.
problem_solved: Offline feed-forward reconstructions (e.g., VGGT, Ï€^3) achieve great quality but require quadratic memory across time, preventing streaming on long/real-time videos and forcing expensive retraining for streaming alternatives.
method: Training-free conversion: take a pretrained feed-forward 4D model and adapt it for streaming at inference time without weight updates.
Layer-wise scale alignment: adjust per-layer activation scales/statistics across temporal windows so features remain stable and causal when processed incrementally.
Memory-efficient buffering & temporal aggregation: reuse aligned layer outputs and maintain lightweight buffers to achieve near-linear memory cost while preserving reconstruction quality.
impact: Enables practitioners to deploy state-of-the-art offline reconstruction models in streaming/real-time pipelines without retraining or large memory overhead, lowering deployment cost and accelerating real-world applications (AR/robotics/live capture).
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: left = pretrained offline model, middle = LASER layer-wise alignment module, right = streaming inference output (frames over time).
Memory chart: quadratic memory vs. LASER's near-linear memory curve for longer sequences (log-scale).
Before/after frames: side-by-side reconstructions from offline model (batched) vs. LASER-streamed output showing preserved quality.
Schematic of layer-wise scale alignment: feature maps with scale/mean adjustments and a small buffer indicating causal reuse.
paper_title: LASER: Layer-wise Scale Alignment for Training-Free Streaming 4D Reconstruction
paper_authors: Tianye Ding, Yiming Xie, Yiqing Liang, Moitreya Chatterjee, Pedro Miraldo
